channel.title: Big Local Kirk Hallam
channel.description: £1m over 10 years for residents led by residents

wp:category.wp:category_description: Useful background information to Big Local and Big Kirk Hallam
Details of the Big Kirk Hallam Community Chest and Star People Awards

Here you can find more about the Big Kirk Hallam plan, what the themes and priorities are, what we plan to spend the £1m on and what we hope will change as a result to help make Kirk Hallam an even better place to live

The whole purpose of Big Kirk Hallam is to help make a difference and support residents to make Kirk Hallam an even better place to live. So here you can find out more about what the money has been spent on, what activity has taken place and what has changed as a result.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: timgdavies
item.content:encoded:
Big Kirk Hallam is a scheme to spend £1 million pounds over ten years on community projects and is paid for with lottery money.
Our vision is to help make Kirk Hallam an even better place to live through fostering community spirit and increasing companionship, improving the opportunities we have and the environment in which we live.

item.title: Big Local in Kirk Hallam
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
Kirk Hallam

East Midlands

Kirk Hallam Big Local area is in Erewash, Derbyshire. Around 6,000 people live in the area, which was historically agricultural. The population expanded dramatically in the 1950s and 1960s, as large housing developments were built.  Firstly public sector housing was built in the 1950s by Ilkeston Corporation and local employer Stanton and Staveley. In the 1960s and 1970s a mix of public and private housing was developed.

Local Trust and partners are pleased to be engaging and supporting the residents and those who work in this Big Local area to get started on their Big Local journey. Contact us below if you are from this area and would like to get involved

item.title: Dallimore Primary School young people set out hopes for Kirk Hallam
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
On Friday 14 December, 2012, young people from the school council started the conversation about what they liked about Kirk Hallam and what could be better. Here is a short report that summarises what they said and groups their ideas under four main areas:
  • People and how we treat each other
  • School
  • Outside
  • Shops
  • Houses and homes
Big Local Kirk Hallam Dallimore School Council meeting Dec 12

item.title: Ladywood Primary School talk about making Kirk Hallam an even better place
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
On December 19 2012, a group of students and teachers met to talk about what was good about Kirk Hallam and what could make it even better.  What we did The group wrote on heart shaped postits the things they liked about Kirk Hallam and then on gold bars the things they think could be better. These have been grouped together in teh report to show the main areas and priorities of the children and young people.  The main areas explored by the group were:
  • People and how we treat each other
  • Homes and community
  • School
  • Outside
  • Things to do
  • Shops
These ideas will be fed into the thinking and planning about how Big Local can make a big difference in the area.
Big Local Kirk Hallam Ladywood School Council meeting Dec 12

item.title: A brief update from Bill Badham
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Dear residents and friends of Kirk Hallam As we approach our first community meeting for Big Local in Kirk Hallam on Friday 18th, I wanted to give a brief update and to thank you for all the interest and support given. Big Local is a resident led, Lottery funded, 10 year programme looking to achieve long lasting change on the community’s issues and priorities. My role is to help get things started and then to support and advice a local group as it takes shape and helps develop a shared vision and plan of action. The response from young and not so young residents and the support from you and those working in the area has been heartening. We have our first big community meeting on Friday at Kenilworth Hall from 5.30 to 7pm. The plan is to share the good things about Kirk Hallam, explore a vision of how things could be improved, consider some emerging priorities and agree on the way forward, with Big Local as a catalyst. We are encouraging people to think about three levels of interest and action: wanting to keep in touch; happy to help do things; and willing to help shape and steer developments, especially in these early stages. Action groups based on the community’s priorities are likely to be key to progress and success, supported by those working in these specialist areas. I hope you will be happy to retain your link and involvement with Big Local as time, interest and local priorities determine. Meanwhile, as Local Rep, please do get in touch for any further information or thoughts. And finally, we are using this web space for the moment to keep track of activity and community conversations across Big Local Kirk Hallam. http://big-local-kirk-hallam.posterous.com/ My thanks and best wishes and I look forward to tomorrow’s meeting. Bill Bill Badham Big Local Rep bill@practicalparticipation.co.uk 07540138967 Twitter: @billbadham http://www.localtrust.org.uk/?project=kirk-hallam http://big-local-kirk-hallam.posterous.com/

item.title: Technology College students speak about making Kirk Hallam an even better place to live
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
Young people met over two School COuncil meetings to consider what's good about teh area and what could be better. They have also done two short interviews which are on this site are making a survey monkey questionnaire to use across the school. Some of the things the group like about Kirk Hallam include:
  • Some teachers
  • Activities at dinner
  • The new park
  • Range of clubs
  • Hockey   
  • Our sports facilities
  • The shops  
  • The social club
  • The fields
Things to do to make Kirk Hallam an even better place to live  These ideas are grouped together under three headings. The full report is attached.
  • Things to do and places to
  • A stronger community
  • A nicer environment
    Here is the report: Tech College Big Local conversation Jan 13

item.title: Making Kirk Hallam an even better place to live – some thoughts from Ken Udall
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
In this blog, Ken Udall speaks about Kirk Hallam history, recent changes and future homes. Ken is a recently retired aerospace engineer at Rolls Royce and vice chairman of Kirk Hallam Community Hall. What's good about Kirk Hallam?  It used to be the murder capital of Ilkeston, but private purchase of council houses and the transfer of the Balloon Woods "sink" estate to Cotmanhay passed this dubious honour to the other side of Ilkeston.  The transfer of the West Hallam secondary school pupils from Ilkeston to Kirk Hallam benefited "The Comp" school of Kirk Hallam.  The estate was built rapidly after the war and in the 1970's, but then stabilised, and many have settled here for a long period, giving a stable multi-generational society.  Low Kirk Hallam house prices relative to surrounding areas has also tended to discourage "emigration".  The estate is of compact form, and sufficiently isolated from Ilkeston to have its own identity.  It is large enough for many needs to be met locally (Petrol, Doctors, Dentists, two supermarkets, Post Office, Chemist, Chip Shop, Newsagents, Church, Community Hall, 2 Pubs, 2 primary and 2 secondary schools, etc).  The "Friends of Kirk Hallam Church" have made the churchyard a beautiful place, so that the old church is a popular wedding venue.  The large churchyard still has plenty of space, so many funerals also take place here, aiding social cohesion, and giving care at a vulnerable time.  The portakabin "Friendship House" fits the "ordinariness" and functionality of the place, but is a useful facility.  There is now also a "Friends of Kirk Hallam Lake", etc.  Beautiful and historic Dale Abbey is within walking distance, as is the very rare post windmill.  The last miller's widow, Peggy Smedley, lives near the church. (She moved to Kirk Hallam when she "retired" from getting up at 3 in the morning to turn the mill round because the wind had changed direction)! What's your vision for the area? A productive godly community, where vandalism, etc, is a distant memory, and where the prayer heritage of Dale Abbey becomes a flood of future blessing to the whole of the Erewash Valley. What are your top 3 priorities for change in Kirk Hallam? My first priority for Kirk Hallam is Industry (ideally on the Stanton Ironworks site). My second priority for the Kirk Hallam situation is a healthy family life (Conception, Love, Security, Significance, etc). So things like Sure Start, "Marriage Discovery", etc might be a good focus for Big Local (priority 2). "Temperature" could be an interesting focus, given the current British dependence on foreign gas, oil, coal, etc.  Being parochial, the Community Hall insulation, and gas heating, or air source heat pump project, could be a good Big Local project, and there may be many other large and small buildings that could benefit from, say, a free thermal camera survey, (priority 3).  
Ken_Udall_vision_and_priorities.pdf
Ken Udall Kirk Hallam resident
item.excerpt:encoded: In this blog, Ken Udall speaks about Kirk Hallam history, recent changes and future homes. Ken is a recently retired aerospace engineer at Rolls Royce and vice chairman of Kirk Hallam Community Hall. What's good about Kirk Hallam? It used to be th...

item.title: What we love about Kirk Hallam and our vision for the future
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
At our first community meeting on Friday 18 January, 40 of us of all ages beat off the earthquake, snow and blizzards and talked about what we love about Kirk Hallam and our vision for the future. Here are our thoughts.   What we love about Kirk Hallam   Those at the meeting drew and wrote their favourite things about the area. This adds to a range of reflection already gathered and now on the web. A few people at the event said how good it was to first focus on the things people liked. It reminds us of the positives we have to build on.   Here are the small groups’ things we like about Kirk Hallam   1. Semi-rural; Kirk Hallam lake; almost self-sufficient in terms of shops and services. Well connected with transport links to Nottingham and Derby. Good choice of school. Thriving church. Excellent sports hall.   2. Pioneer Meadow, Nutbrook trail, Kirk Hallam lake and surrounding area, daffodils down Deepdale, primary schools, cat and fiddle pub, church and church yard.   3. Mix of age groups, community spirit, friendly people, Nutbrook trail, lake, heritage, green spaces, schools, bus service, SureStart, Coop.   4. People and the strong sense of community spirit. The good things that link to this are: family connections, in and around open spaces, local shops like the post office, bus routes central, church, social club / fishing, large plots, local eatery, community college.   5. Good areas for walking dogs etc, good bus service, local dentist, doctor and chemist, local shops, schools within walking distance, local places to eat, community hall for functions.   6. A good community with most services available.

·        Accessibility: countryside, towns, visitor sites all in the same place

·        History: one of the oldest churches in the UK

·        Community: good friends

·        Friends and community groups

·        Schools and teachers

·        Doctors and caring people

·        Lake and meadows

  Our vision for Kirk Hallam Small groups then shared what their vision was for Kirk Hallam. Some of things of course already exist and it is about keeping them and developing them. Other ideas are new.   1. Our vision is for pride in the community from all ages

·        Good schools to attract good teachers

·        Beautiful public open spaces

·        Facilitie4s for everyone but especially children

·        User friendly access sites and facilities

  2. Our vision is for a happy community with better opportunities, valued and respected inside and beyond the Borough, with a longer active life expectancy.   3. Our vision is to have a better Kirk Hallam by 2023

·        Get things back to their former glory

·        Kirk Hallam in bloom

·        Contented teenagers

·        Better partnerships with schools

·        Improving what we already have

·        To take the opportunity to do good

·        Better community spirit (of then non-alcoholic variety).

  4. Our vision for Kirk Hallam is to have a stronger identity:

·        A local community market and better, tidier shops

·        Industrial site with jobs

·        Community allotments

·        Big focal point, building – somewhere to holed celebrations and community events for everyone.

  5. Our vision for Kirk Hallam is for a stronger community spirit:

·        Carnival

·        More use of the community hall for events etc

·        Better lighting and barriers in gities etc

·        Feeling safe at night

·        Safe

·        Somewhere to take children.

  6. Kirk Hallam K – Kirk Hallam and the future we see I – It’s positively the best place to be R – Rich in spirit and community life K – Kids need something to reduce the strife   H – Happy to receive the Lottery money A – And make Kirk Hallam flow with milk and honey L – Looking after the elderly and not leaving them alone L – Lifting the problems to which they are prone A – All together we can make it happen too M – Motivate, elevate, jubilate create for you!
item.excerpt:encoded: At our first community meeting on Friday 18 January, 40 of us of all ages beat off the earthquake, snow and blizzards and talked about what we love about Kirk Hallam and our vision for the future. Here are our thoughts.What we love about Kirk Hall...

item.title: Things we can do to improve Kirk Hallam now and for the future
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
Things that aren’t so good and we would like to change in Kirk Hallam On the website are a number of community conversations which include people’s priorities for change. We are beginning to see some important themes for residents across the ages and interests. The write up below shows areas of concern and desire for action from those taking part on 18 January. In writing this report, the ideas from the 6 small groups have been grouped under common themes. They are all now phrased as actions and things to be done. If a concern has for example x 2 next to it, it is because the issue was raised by two different groups. The main areas identified for action group round:

·        Things to do and places to go

·        Safety

·        Schools, education, training and jobs

·        Community spirit and supporting community groups

·        The environment

Things to do and places to go

·        Improve facilities for young people x2

·        Get a youth club

·        There need to be more events or activities for families and children, especially during half term

·        Spaces and activities are needed for children and young people

·        Improve childcare facilities x2

Safety

·        Need better spot lighting provision

·        Street lighting is poor and needs improving

·        Shop area needs to be safer; they feel unsafe at night with groups of teenagers hanging around

·        Action needs to be taken to tackle drugs and alcohol issues, especially around Queen Elizabeth Way Shops

·        Tackle the gangs gathering around the top shops

·        Reduce anti-social behaviour

·        Reduce vandalism

Schools, education, training and job opportunities

·        Improve after school facilities

·        Improve nursery facilities

·        Apprentiship schemes required at local schools

·        There needs to be more local job opportunities

·        Secondary schools

Community spirit and supporting community groups

·        We need to improve the poor finance for community groups

·        We need more community events

·        We need to act to reduce the community split between sides of the main road which makes it like 2 different communities.

·        We need to reduce the isolation of old people

·        Improve the heating in the community hall

·        Revamp the tired community hall

·        Improve community spirit

·        Need a community bus

Environment

·        Grass verge policy in need of urgent review x3

·        Parks are rubbish and dirty and need improving x2

·        There need to be more grit boxes x 3

·        It is unsafe for outdoor activity areas eg bike rides and this needs improving

·        The pavements are awful and need improving

·        We want places to stop and sit

·        Dog mess needs sorting x2

·        We need more visual character and distinctiveness

·        Problem with narrow roads needs addressing

·        Lakeside could do with more tidiness

·        We need to improve the appearance and cleanliness of the area

·        We need to reduce car parking on bus routes

·        Stop bikes using the gities

·        Reduce the speed along Ladywood Road

·        Improve access for elderly residents

·        Improve lighting and car parking around church drive

·        Reduce litter

·        Improve bus service including to the shops x2
item.excerpt:encoded: Things that aren’t so good and we would like to change in Kirk Hallam On the website are a number of community conversations which include people’s priorities for change. We are beginning to see some important themes for residents across the a...

item.title: What we need as a group of residents to help make these changes happen
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
The whole group thought about what we need to help us make the changes we want to see happen in Kirk Hallam through Big Local. What are the values and virtues (Heart) to hold us on course, the knowledge (Head) to guide us and skills (Hands) to get on and do stuff? Points were written on postits and added to a large sticky wall plotting our journey from where we are now to our vision for the future. These postits are grouped in the list below. They don’t all fit that neatly but it works reasonably well.  The list is mainly what we need from ourselves, with just a few things we may need from others. And what we mainly need from ourselves according to this group is a big Heart. From us as residents and volunteers in the community we need: Heart – the values and virtues to keep us on track

·        Vision

·        A sense of common purpose

·        Bravery – the ability to think big and go for it

·        Motivation

·        Enthusiasm

·        Strength

·        Confidence

·        Resident participation

·        Resident input of all ages

·        Energy and focus

·        Community disagreement and the ability to work through this

·        Enthusiasm and support from local councillors living in the area

·        A sense and belief that we can do it

·        Good will

·        Faith

·        Hope

·        Patience

·        A can-do attitude

·        Empowerment

·        Involvement of all

·        Commitment

Head – the knowledge we need

·        Interest

·        Finance and financial acumen

·        Knowing the needs of the area

·        Ideas

·        A shopping list

Hands - the skills and resources we need

·        Skills

·        Ability

·        Advice

·        Time

·        A need to get agreement from lots of very different people

·        Communication skills

·        Communications network – 2 way

·        Local newsletter

·        Identifying key skills and matching to abilities of volunteers

·        Practical skills

·        Planning a plan for the future

·        Organisational and project management skills

From others

·        Support from local businesses

·        Professional help and advice

·        Financial advice

·        Enthusiasm and support from local councillors living in the area
item.excerpt:encoded: The whole group thought about what we need to help us make the changes we want to see happen in Kirk Hallam through Big Local. What are the values and virtues (Heart) to hold us on course, the knowledge (Head) to guide us and skills (Hands) to get...

item.title: Sara Phillips talks about regaining community spirit
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Sara has lived in Kirk Hallam and would love to see Big Local helping to strengthened community spirit through reviving things like the carnivals and New Year festival. [wpvideo mNOUjuTC]

item.title: Report from first community meeting
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
Here is the report from the first Big Local Kirk Hallam community meeting. Chunks of it have appeared as separate blogs on what we love about the area, our vision and priorities for action. We have also posted interviews with two who came on the night as well as all the photos of people talking part and of the flipcharts of what we did. This report brings all that into one place and is a record of the energy and excitement on the night, coupled with clear vision for what can be achieved through resident leadership of Big Local and some emerging ideas and priorities for action.
The full report:
Big Local Kirk Hallam community meeting report 18Jan13
item.excerpt:encoded: Here is the report from the first Big Local Kirk Hallam community meeting. Chunks of it have appeared as separate blogs on what we love about the area, our vision and priorities for action. We have also posted interviews with two who came on the n...

item.title: Big Local Kirk Hallam first community meeting in photos
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Here is the first community meeting in photos:   38 people took part. 26 were residents. 34 want to stay in touch. 27 want to help take action. 13 are happy to help steer next steps in taking Big Local forward in Kirk Hallam. These photos show what we did and form part of the growing community conversation about what people like about Kirk Hallam, what the vision is for Kirk Hallam’s future, what are the difficulties and what are the priorities for action. The full report is also on this site, along with videos from two people who took part.
item.excerpt:encoded: Here is the first community meeting in photos: 38 people took part. 26 were residents. 34 want to stay in touch. 27 want to help take action. 13 are happy to help steer next steps in taking Big Local forward in Kirk Hallam. These photos show what ...

item.title: Big Local Kirk Hallam - a bright forecast ahead
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
Big Local Kirk Hallam BB 130125.docx
Getting started with Big Local Kirk Hallam is making headway, avoiding being shaken by the earthquake, sliding on the ice or getting lost in the snowdrift.   At the first community meeting on 18 January in the snow, 38 people took part. 26 were residents. 34 want to stay in touch. 27 want to help take action. 13 are happy to help steer next steps in taking Big Local forward in Kirk Hallam. About 60 other residents have also fed back their ideas about what they love about the area, their vision and priorities for the future. These include about 30 children and young people from across two primary schools and the Technology college school councils.   Interviews, photos and reports are all on this site.    While early days, what is encouraging though not surprising is that there is a lot of similarity across age and interest groups about the things people love about Kirk Hallam, their vision for what Big Local can help achieve and their priorities for change. People value the community spirit, the open spaces, great schools, shops and local services and community hall. And these are mainly the things many feel can be improved upon through better resourcing, improved amenities and things to do and places to go for children and young people and their families. Young people talk about better support for adults with addictions. Elderly residents talk about better facililies for the young.   We have a long way to go and no doubt many more snowdrifts to plough through and icy patches to navigate, but Kirk Hallam Big Local is showing the desire and commitment to work together for the long term common good. And that is a bright forecast for everyone.   Bill Badham Big Local Rep Kirk Hallam January 2013
item.excerpt:encoded: Getting started with Big Local Kirk Hallam is making headway, avoiding being shaken by the earthquake, sliding on the ice or getting lost in the snowdrift. At the first community meeting on 18 January in the snow, 38 people took part. 26 were resi...

item.title: BBC Radio Derby Phil Trow in conversation with Bill Badham
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: On Monday 28 January, Phil Trow from BBC Radio Derby talked to Big Local Rep, Bill Badham, about Big Local in Kirk Hallam and the steps residents are already taking to make the area an even better place to live.   Listen again to Phil Trow's Radio Derby breakfast show interview with 45 minute in here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p0137t44
item.excerpt:encoded: On Monday 28 January, Phil Trow from BBC Radio Derby talked to Big Local Rep, Bill Badham, about Big Local in Kirk Hallam and the steps residents are already taking to make the area an even better place to live. Listen again to Phil Trow's Radio D...

item.title: Pool facility for young people closes in Kirk Hallam
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
News today is that the pool room at the Nottingham Castle pub in Kirk Hallam can no longer be sued by young people due to action by the Licencing Authorities. 

This is such a shame in an area where local people are looking to take action to offer young people things to do and places to go.

As the Big Local Rep for Kirk Hallam's £1m over 10 years Big Lottery funding, it is clear to me that more facilities and activities for young people unite the community across ages and interests. In community conversations in schools and at resident meetings, this is one of the top emerging priorities.

So to lose one of the few popular and well used resources in this way is quite a set back. I am sure residents and community activists will find a way forward.

Landlord_ordered_to_shut_pub_youth_club_-_Ilkeston_News_Jan13.pdf
item.excerpt:encoded: News today is that the pool room at the Nottingham Castle pub in Kirk Hallam can no longer be sued by young people due to action by the Licencing Authorities. This is such a shame in an area where local people are looking to take action to offer y...

item.title: A short update on progress with Big Local Kirk Hallam
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
We are really pleased at the results of the first Big Local Kirk Hallam community meeting on 18 January. Our report is on this site. You can also follow and contribute to the Big Local Kirk Hallam story at http://bigkirkhallam.wordpress.com 

·        Community conversation has short reports from each event held so far, including with three of the four schools.

·        Photos, video, voice has some short interviews with residents, a link to an interview on Radio Derby and photos from the communtiy event on 18 January

·        You can also check out the News and Background sections for further infomration and articles.

About 100 residents and people working in the area have so far said they want to keep in touch and feed in ideas. About 40 people want to take action. And a small group of about 12 residents are helping steer these early stages. Notes of steering group meetings will go up on the website. Watch out for further community events and conversations these coming months and make a note of Friday afternoon of 12 April to come down to Kennilworth Community Hall at any time for an update on progress and to help shape next steps. On behalf of the Big Local Kirk Hallam steering group – our thanks and we look forward to widening the conversation and deepening our understanding of needs and priorities to build a plan that can best help make Kirk Hallam and event better place to live.
item.excerpt:encoded: We are really pleased at the results of the first Big Local Kirk Hallam community meeting on 18 January. Our report is on this site. You can also follow and contribute to the Big Local Kirk Hallam story at http://big-local-kirk-hallam.posterous.co...

At our first steering group meeting on 28 January, we looked at our role in representing residents and supporting as many as possible to have their voices heard and influence emerging priorities for action. We outlined some of the key tasks we needed to look at to take Big Local in Kirk Hallam forward.

item.title: Emerging priorities and themes
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
There are 15 emerging priorities which can be grouped into 4 themes arising from the community conversation so far through Big Local Kirk Hallam. There is a range of further opportunity to widen and deepen understanding, leading to our second large community meeting on 12 April at the Community Hall on Kenilworth Drive.   Things to do and places to go

·        Things to do and places to go for children and young people

·        Things to do and places to go for young people

·        Things to do and places to go for older residents

·        Transport

·        Improved facilities outside

·        Improving facilities indoors

  Access and environment

·        A nicer environment

·        Shops

·        Disabled access to shops

  Quality of life

·        Safety through tackling vandalism

·        Supporting vulnerable people and families (drugs and alcohol)

·        Community spirit and celebration

·        Improving quality of life through tacking poverty

  Education and training

·        Apprentiships, training and jobs

·        Improved nursery and after school facilities

item.title: Dads speak out about support to families with young children
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
On Saturday 2 March, on a gorgeous sunny day, two residents on the steering group, Tracy and Julie, went with Bill the Big Local Rep, to meet up with the dads’ group which meets every week at the SureStart and Children’s Centre in Kirk Hallam.
  While we also enjoyed playing with the children, being offered very tasty baked play dough biscuits, it was important to hear from the dads about what was good and what was not so good about being a parent in Kirk Hallam with very young children and what could be done to improve things. The short report says it all.  Here is the report from our meeting: Big Kirk Hallam Dads' group 2 March 2013
item.excerpt:encoded: On Saturday 2 March, on a gorgeous sunny day, two residents on the steering group, Tracy and Julie, went with Bill the Big Local Rep, to meet up with the dads’ group which meets every week at the SureStart and Children’s Centre in Kirk Hallam. Whi...

item.title: Big Local highlighted in new report about local actions and solutions
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
Big Local is highlighted in new report by Respublica – ‘Responsible Recovery: a social contract for local growth’

 

The report supports the belief that is central to Big Local – that people are the solution. The report says:

 

Big Local is a long term innovative programme delivered by Local Trust and funded by the Big Lottery Fund that enables and supports residents in 150 small communities throughout England to make their areas even better over at least the next 10 years. Over this period each area will be supported by Local Trust and partners to spend or invest at least £1m.

 

Big Local brings together all the local talent, ambitions, skills and energy from individuals, groups and organisations who want to make their area an even better place to live. Residents identify the issues in their areas that they want to address and work together to put a plan together for how they will do this and then do it!

 

The report encourages government and local authorities to promote community participation, and highlights how they can learn from Big Local. The report says that ‘unlike traditional government programmes, (through Big Local) there are no restrictions on when the money should be spent – the emphasis is on identifying local needs and enabling communities to develop the skills and capacity to address them.’

 

Find out more about the report and download it from the Respublica website –http://www.respublica.org.uk/item/Responsible-Recovery-A-social-contract-for-local-growth.
item.excerpt:encoded: Big Local is highlighted in new report by Respublica – ‘Responsible Recovery: a social contract for local growth’ The report supports the belief that is central to Big Local – that people are the solution. The report says: Big Local is a l...

Big Local Kirk Hallam 3rd SG 18 Feb 13.docx
At our third meeting on 18 February, the steering group agreed our main messages and next steps in finding a local trusted organisation to support us. We looked at and planned a range of small group meetings to continue and deepen the community conversation.
item.excerpt:encoded: At our third meeting on 18 February, the steering group agreed our main messages and next steps in finding a local trusted organisation to support us. We looked at and planned a range of small group meetings to continue and deepen the community co...

item.title: Steering group 4th meeting
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Here are our notes from our fourth steering group meeting on 4 March. Our focus was on planning the next large community event on Friday 12 April. We also reviewed recent activity and planned meeting and events coming up in the next few weeks. We agreed to keep a log or scrap book of all that’s been happening as a record of the Big Kirk Hallam journey. Big Local Kirk Hallam 4th SG 4 Mar 13.docx

item.title: 5th Steering group meeting notes
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: The Steering group welcomed our latest member, Aidan Smith, Vice Principal of the Technology College. He and Peter Hamer, Principal, will represent the college as the Local Trusted Organisation. Our focus was on agreeing next steps with the Local Trusted Organisation, reviewing activity and planning the next community event on Friday 12 April. We also reflected on our hopes, fears and achievements as a group. Big Local Kirk Hallam 5th SG 21 Mar 13.docx

item.title: 6th Steering group meeting on 15 April 2013
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Our focus was on reviewing the community meeting on 12 April and agreeing next steps through our action plan. We are drafting the Getting Started application for £20,000, with £10,000 toward running things and supporting events and £10,000 toward people doing things through a community chest. Three steering group members attended a resident Big Local event and reported that it was helpful to see the progress we are making and the creative ideas from elsewhere we can draw on, like Star People and building in evaluation as we go along. Big Local Kirk Hallam 6th SG 15Ap13

item.title: A short report from the community conversation on 12 April
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
The event was about residents being involved in thinking and planning priorities and funding activity to make a lasting and positive difference to Kirk Hallam 65 people took part. 47 were residents and 18 were not residents but worked in the area. Feedback was very positive and the planning group felt confident the event had met its aims. “Thank you for all this... it was a great event - well organised with such a lovely atmosphere and the steady stream of people really made it work. Really enjoyed it.” We felt the event had gone well because:
  • People left knowing more about Big Kirk Hallam.
  • People were interested and involved.
  • People took part in saying how Kirk Hallam can be an even better place to live.
Here is the full report: Big Kirk Hallam report 12 April 2013

item.title: 12 April 2013 community conversation about our vision for Big Kirk Hallam
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Here is a colourful and detailed account from Gillian Bates working with Washarts to help residents create a vision and logo for Big Kirk Hallam. The report is full of poems, pictures and priceless ideas. Here is the full report: Kirk Hallam Report washarts April 2013

item.title: 3 Kirk Hallam schools join forces to share their views and vision for Kirk Hallam
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: On 21 March, Ladywood Primary School hosted a joint schools event with Dallimore Primary School for the children to share their photographs and stories of what they like and what could be better about Kirk Hallam. They were joined by four young people from the Technology College, reporting on the event. Macie, Victor, Matthew and Matthew listened in, drew out some of the main ideas and themes, posed questions and wrote a short article about the day. Here is the full report: Dalliwood joint schools report 21 March13

item.title: Kirk Hallam Community College surveys 1200 students
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: During February 2013, the student council devised, distributed, collated and analysed findings from across 17 classed and 12000 students. The report is attached here and gives a great insight into what young people like about Kirk Hallam and what they feel could be better. Here is the report: Kirk Hallam Tech College Big Local survey results Feb 2013

item.title: Things to do and places to go for children and families
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
A meeting with the Sure Start Parents group on 16 April 2013 What we found To explore this emerging community priority, Tracy, Julie and Bill went to meet and talk with the parents group at Sure Start on Tuesday 16 April, 2013. We met with Claire, Alex, Katarryna and Vicky. They were especially keen that Big Kirk Hallam supports them and other resident groups to run things themselves and take ownership of what change and improvements they want to see happen. There were three main themes emerging: · More groups and training opportunities o Keen to promote more groups, Tumbletots, Yoga groups etc for the children. o Arts and crafts sessions, need space to do these groups. o After school clubs. · Shared community space o Volunteering opportunities o Paid work · More inclusive parks and outdoor place spaces for all ages. o Adult Park, Victoria Park, Belfast, 0-3 section older section, than adult part. o A skate park There was also a conversation about quality of life and helping people in difficult circumstances, especially through for example the Credit Union. The group looked at how it would allocate money to the 4 main emerging themes and decided out of 100% it would apportion spend as in the table below. On the right are the figures from the community meeting on 12 April.
Priority areas for action Parents group % split Community meeting % split
Things to do and places to go 50% 43.16%
Access and environment 10% 25.64%
Quality of life 15% 22.22%
Education and training 25% 8.97%
In contrast to the community meeting, the parents group wanted to see: · A bit more spent on things to do and places to · Quite a lot less on access and the environment · A bit less on quality of life and · A lot more on education and training. What happens next · The report will be written up and shared with the group and posted on our website. · The conversation and findings will be added to our profile report guiding the whole of Big Kirk Hallam over the coming years. · An invitation will be given to the group to consider applying for the small grants community chest when launched on 7 July. · An invitation is extended to members of the group to take part in supporting the development and activity of Big Kirk Hallam. Julie Brown, Tracy Thorp, Bill Badham SureStart Parents Group Short report 16 Ap13.pdf

item.title: Big Kirk Hallam Frequently Asked Questions
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Here are some frequently asked questions on the first sheet. Have a go if you want, giving your answers on the first sheet and then compare them with our short summaries on the second page. Or just go straight to the answers! FAQ.docx

item.title: Big Kirk Hallam community chest training report
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: And here it is! We covered loads of stuff, including building agreement about the criteria we would look to use as a grant making panel, our understanding of what Big Kirk Hallam looks to achieve, our ability to support people to apply, our ability to make decisions and to do so fairly. The Big Kirk Hallam community chest will be launched on 7 July at the Lakes and Meadows event. Big KH Community Chest training report June 13

item.title: Big Kirk Hallam News Issue 1 summer 2013
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Here is our first newsletter from Big Kirk Hallam. You’ll find in it a summary of what we have done so far, the emerging community priorities for action, how to apply for money from the Big Kirk Hallam community chest and Star People Awards, where to find us over the summer and how to keep in touch. We hope you enjoy it and please let us know what you think by emailing admin Big Kirk Hallam A4 leaflet Summer 2013.pdf

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Keep up the good work Big Kirk Hallam x
Thank you Julie - you have been an inspiration from the start and a great example to all residents wanting to work for the greater community good.

item.title: 7th Steering group meeting notes
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Here are the notes of the May steering group meeting held at the college. These are open meetings held at the college between 5.30 and 7pm on the second Monday of every month. (We won’t be meeting in August.) We had a full meeting. · The group welcomed Peter Hamer and thanked him for the college’s role as our local trusted organisation. · The group wanted to record with thanks Julie Brown’s vital contribution in getting us started and wishes her well as she moves on to other things. · The group also thanked Brian and Hazel for the warm welcome and hospitality over our first meetings in getting started. We discussed and agreed the steering group’s Terms of Reference and signed these. The group elected Brian Cooper as Chair of Steering group. We updated the Action plan, including signing off the first Big Kirk Hallam newsletter and the community chest information. Big Kirk Hallam 7thSG 15 May 2013 notes.docx

item.title: 8th Big Kirk Hallam steering group meeting June 2013
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Here are the notes of the June Steering Group. The next one will be on 9 September 5.30 to 7pm at Kirk Hallam College and these are open to all. At the June meeting key decisions are summarised below. Some key actions from action plan updated 17 June 2013: · Getting started agreement: Aidan to sign and return to Local Trust and pass a copy for the file to Hazel W; Aidan and Colin finalising financial processes for accessing money. · Big events: Natalia has the T shirts and will link with Aidan to purchase remaining items from remaining budget of £280 · Natalia will devise a rota for the 7th July and circulate this. If you can’t make your slot then please arrange a swop and let Natalia know. · Bill will draft agreement letter with groups we are funding and pass to Aidan and Colin for approval · Aidan and Colin will send this to Lakes and Meadows, Fun day, Harvest Moon and Autumn Fair organisers for agreement, signing and releasing £500 to each group. · Bill will draw up shortlist of logo ideas and drafted vision for community comment on 7 July. · Colin, Hazel and Bill will consider comms plan for developing content and building a network · College is typing up further contacts and Aidan and Nick will ensure new @bigkirkhallam email addresses are up and running and on the leaflet for printing and A4 version for email distribution · Colin will distribute e-copies to our database. We also have hard copies going out to the bottom half of the estate for £20, led by Brian · Colin and Hazel W will do further work on community profile by 8 July · Bill will look at process for building detail of eventual delivery plan through small themed focused groups, ideally with lead organisation partner · Natalia and Bill are leading the community chest training evening on Thurs 20 June Big Kirk Hallam 8thSG 17 June 2013 notes.docx

We have an information session on 21 August at the college when you can find out more. There are grants for local groups and organisations and also awards for enterprising people. item.content:encoded: Remember the Community Chest information sessions are this week! It's your chance to improve opportunities and local life in the area. It's at the college, 11-1pm, and 5-7pm on Wednesday 21st August.

item.title: Big Kirk Hallam' report on conversations with older residents
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Here is a short and detailed report from Big Kirk Hallam arising from a series of focus groups with older residents sharing what could be done to improve their experiences of things to do and places to go locally. These findings will feed into the Big Kirk Hallam plan which being developed over the autumn. Our thanks to Emma Lees of Three Valleys Housing for coordinating the group sessions and compiling the report and to Linda Frudd, Julie Brown and Hazel Cooper for co-facilitating the groups. Big KH older people conversations July 13.pdf

item.title: Big Local August newsletter
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: The August Big Local newsletter is out and includes: § News on two learning events coming up - Access to credit and Big Local and transport. As well as lots of handy resources on our recent event on local media. § Information on the boosting the economy pilot which areas can apply for. § Blogs and opportunities. Here is the link: http://createsend.com/t/j-0FA3D50EC2ECC484

item.title: Notes of the steering group meeting in July 2013
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
Here are the notes from the 9th Big Kirk Hallam steering group, held in July 2013. The meeting was introduced by the chair, Brian Cooper: “We are a tree with deepening roots and there are 4 branches holding our work and creating seeds that will bear further fruit and require further action and demands.” These branches sustaining our work are:
  • Maintaining and developing the steering group
  • Deepening the conversation
  • Communicating the message
  • Taking action on community priorities
“We have our profile and themes and priorities for action. We now need support to help build on this to build our Big Local Plan.” The steering group agreed to recruit and appoint someone to coordinate building the plan between September and December 2013. Big Kirk Hallam SG 8 July 2013.doc

item.title: Congratulations for our Logo Competition Winners!
item.dc:creator: linuxparadise
item.content:encoded:
Congratulations for our Logo Competition Winners!

The two winners of the logo competition were announced on Monday at the school. From left to right: Hazel, Courtney and Brian. They both got £20 each, well done and thank you!

item.title: Mark is the new Plan Co-ordinator
item.dc:creator: linuxparadise
item.content:encoded:
Mark is the new Plan Co-ordinator

The steering group have just recently hired a plan co-ordinator to figure out exactly what to spend the money on, with the steering group's help of course. He will help with preparing a business plan to send to the folks at Big Local (the lottery). He has just recently moved to Kirk Hallam this spring, having previously served in the army in job roles similar to this one.

item.title: Building the plan
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Mark Sheath is our new plan coordinator and he is working with Big Kirk Hallam over the coming 4 months to draw on the community conversation to build our first delivery plan to draw on the £1m. You can contact Mark at plan@bigkirkhallam.org.uk

item.title: September's Newsletter
item.dc:creator: linuxparadise
item.content:encoded:
Here is the newsletter for Autumn 2013. Big Kirk Hallam Newsletter Issue 2 The newsletter gets you up to speed about what has been happening and how to get in touch. Here are some of the highlights. What has happened so far! December 2012 - Big Kirk Hallam £1m resident-led programme launched (for the next ten years.) January - June 2013 over 1200 residents have shared priorities for action that Big Kirk Hallam should focus on. A resident-led steering group is established to take these priorities forward. (See Priorities.) May 2013 - Kirk Hallam Community Technology and Sports College chosen as the Local Trusted Organisation to support Big Kirk Hallam and manage the finances.  June 2013 - £20,000 released to help support events over the Summer and to start a Community Chest to give out small grants to local groups to help make Kirk Hallam an even better place to live. For more information about the Community Chest contact: admin@bigkirkhallam.org.uk September 2013 - Big Kirk Hallam appoints a Co-ordinator to construct the plan of how the funds will be allocated and an administrator to help to keep all records in order. A new logo has been designed for use on Big Kirk Hallam literature. The two winning designers were thanked by Steering Group Chair Brian Cooper and presented with a £20 prize for their efforts. What next Over the summer Big Kirk Hallam will be supporting and taking part in a number of big events in the area. We hope that you will come and talk over your hopes and vision to make Kirk Hallam an even better place to live.
  • Autumn Fair at the Kirk Hallam Community Technology and Sports College, 21st September 10am – 3pm
  • Harvest Moon at Pioneer Meadows, off Wirksworth Drive, 21st September 2.30 – 7pm

item.title: First Draft of Kirk Hallam's Profile
item.dc:creator: linuxparadise
item.content:encoded: Here is the first draft of Big Kirk Hallam's profile, which gives a lot of background about Kirk Hallam, and will be used to help create the plan. BKHcomm profile draft Sept 13

item.title: Congratulations to Big Kirk Hallam first award winners
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
On 21 September 2013 our chair, Brian Cooper, announced Big Kirk Hallam’s first group of successful grant applicants at the Community College’s great Autumn Fair.
First up were those who gained £500 grants for running community events over the summer and helping Big Kirk Hallam get its name and message out to a wide number and range of local residents. Esther Collington collected the cheque on behalf of Lakes and Meadows. The other two events sponsored by Big Kirk Hallam were Harvest Moon and the Autumn Fair.
Next up were the awards from the Big Kirk Hallam community chest. This is a grants fund for amounts up to £500 or up to £1000. An application must be led by at least two residents of any age on behalf of a local group. Decision are made by a panel of residents. If you want to get involved email admin.
Congratulations to four groups on their successful applications and we really look forward to hearing what’s happened and celebrating what’s changed with the help of Big Kirk Hallam.
The groups are:
· Kirk Hallam Youth Football Club
· The Drama Group
· The Lunch Club
· And the elder’s gardening project.
Don’t forget the second round is now open and the closing date for applications is 10 December 2013 – our first anniversary!
[gallery]

item.title: What's changed at the Lakes and Meadows summer event
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded:
Esther Collington, Treasurer of the Friends of Lakes and Meadows, recently wrote to our chair to thank Big Kirk Hallam for its support in helping run the very successful Lakes and Meadows event.
Esther writes:
“Please convey to Big Kirk Hallam the Friends of Kirk Hallam Lake thanks for the wonderful grant. The Lakeside Festival was very successful. Many local people came on the day, with children particularly enjoying the pony rides and fairground rides. There was a wildlife theme to the day with pond dipping, birds of prey and the Derbyshire Wildlife Trust educating both children and adults. Some people even said it was the best Festival ever, which places some pressure on us for next year! Thanks again for the much appreciated grant.”
[gallery]

item.title: Starting get growing again
item.dc:creator: billbadham

item.title: Big Kirk Hallam profile
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: To make sure our Big Local plan to spend the £1m is rooted in our local realities, we have researched and put together a report which we call our Profile. This brings together stories about Kirk Hallam, stats and the community conversation, leading to our shared vision, 4 main themes and emerging priorities for action. Below is the brief summary of our Profile. You can download the full document as well. One local professional said: “This is brilliant. We have never had all the information in one place and presented so clearly. Thank you.” We hope you too find it interesting and useful. A short summary Stories: a look back in time The industrial revolution in the 18th and 19th centuries made Kirk Hallam what it is today. It used to be a sleepy little farming community with four farms and a church. The nearby collieries and Stanton iron works made the population swell. Kirk Hallam was annexed to Ilkeston in 1934. The population expanded dramatically in the 1950s and 1960s, as large housing developments were built. First, public sector housing was built in the 1950s by Ilkeston Corporation and local employer Stanton and Staveley. Then in the 1960s and 1970s a mix of public and private housing was developed. Today, around 6,000 people live in the area, which was historically agricultural. The population of Kirk Hallam has gone down since 2001, as people move to find employment after the closure of the big industries. Stats: taking stock of the present Kirk Hallam is a well-defined geographical area of about 6000 residents, with a clear identity, a sense of history and community spirit. There are about 2700 dwellings. There is a wide range of households with significant numbers with dependent children and of older residents. The population is predominantly white and born in the UK. Local challenges, in order of statistical significance, are educational achievement, the living environment, health, crime and barriers to housing and services. Unemployment is slightly higher than the Borough rate and more acute in households with dependent children. Decline in large scale local employment has affected quality of life and living standards. There are however some marked differences in life experience across the Ward’s four neighbourhoods. Residents in the north west enjoy significantly better outcomes than the other three areas. Health outcomes are worst in the north east of Kirk Hallam. Education achievement is poor, except in the north west where it is average. Levels of crime are roughly the same across the Ward, higher in the south side and lower on the north side. Barriers to housing and services are more acute on the east side of the Ward. The living environment is best in the south west and north east of Kirk Hallam. The stats indicate many aspects of Kirk Hallam life and living standards which are comparable to the Borough, region and country as a whole. The overall neighbourhood rankings nonetheless show significant need across a number of indicators and that the level of need varies across the four neighbourhoods in Kirk Hallam. Community conversation: looking got the future Since our launch in December 2012, we have spoken with over 600 people of all ages and across all parts of Kirk Hallam through large events and small group meetings. We have had over 1000 responses to surveys and questionnaires. From this arose four themes and 16 areas for action. These were reviewed by residents at spring and summer events, leading to agreeing our vision and priorities. Our vision Our vision is to help make Kirk Hallam and even better place to live through fostering community spirit and increasing togetherness, improving the opportunities we have and the environment we live in. Our themes and next steps Our four themes that give us the framework for our priorities for action are: 1. Things to do and places to go; 2. Access and the environment; 3. Quality of life; 4, Education and training. Our next steps over the autumn and winter are to develop our first draft Big Local Plan based on our vision and themes arising from our community conversation. Here is the full report BKHcomm profile final Oct 13

item.title: Attached are the minutes of the meeting of the Steering Group from September
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: The group were informed about Three Valleys Housing Association’s work with older members of the community. The group welcomed the appointment of a co-ordinator to develop the “Big Local Plan”. The profile of Kirk Hallam was nearing completion. Applications for the “Community Chest” programme were being submitted and awards were to be announced on 21 September, an eventful day which saw residents attend the Autumn Show at Kirk Hallam Community Technology and Sports College and also the Harvest Moon Festival at Pioneer Meadow Nature Reserve. Big Kirk Hallam SG 9 Sept 13.docx

item.title: Local trust latest newsletter on fair local credit
item.dc:creator: billbadham
item.content:encoded: Interested in fair finance & what people can do to provide access to affordable credit locally? Here is Local Trust’s latest newsletter http://createsend.com/t/j-246170CA230FD3AC Understanding borrowing and saving You've been telling us that access to affordable credit is coming up as an issue in a number of Big Local areas. The high cost of credit in some areas can mean that people have less money to spend on food, clothes and other essentials and it also impacts people's health and causes stress, worry and anxiety. We are now starting to see areas prioritise these issues, and begin to work out how to make social investments into the local credit union to increase the availability of affordable credit to people in the area. Small Change is working with Local Trust to ensure Big Local areas get the support you need to do that, with the reps. They can help Big Local areas to identify and implement investment opportunities, which might include addressing a range of issues including: · payday lending and high interest rates · saving for a ‘rainy day’ · dealing with the implications of how universal credit will affect people’s income · how people are going to receive rental allowances · dealing with debt · local cash points charging to withdraw money. We have lots of information and guidance available on our website. If you have any questions on access to affordable credit and opportunities for social investment, please speak to your rep. Debbie Ladds, chief executive @DebbieLadds
